name: Substantial Refurbishment or Reconstruction
short_description: Landlord intends to demolish, reconstruct or carry out substantial works

landlord_intention.scope: Cannot reasonably be carried out without tenant giving up possession
landlord_intention.timing: Intention must exist at time of court hearing

works_scope.requirement: Works must be substantial and require vacant possession

landlord_ownership.requirement: Landlord must have owned property for at least 2 years
landlord_ownership.exception: Or property devolved under will or intestacy within 2 years

notice_period.court_proceedings: Can be started after notice expires

evidence_required: Detailed plans and specifications of proposed works
Architect or surveyor report confirming works are substantial
Building regulations approval or planning permission (if required)
Evidence works cannot be done with tenant in situ (surveyor report)
Proof of landlord ownership for 2+ years (Land Registry, title deeds)

high_probability: Expert evidence that vacant possession is necessary
Planning permission or building regulations approved
Genuine intention to carry out works promptly
medium_probability: Plans prepared but planning permission pending
Works substantial but some could be done with tenant in situ
Funding not fully secured but obtainable
low_probability: Works could be carried out with tenant remaining
No planning permission or building approval
Insufficient funds to carry out works
Intention not genuine or works speculative

red_flags: Landlord owned property less than 2 years
No evidence works require vacant possession
No planning permission for major alterations
Landlord has history of using Ground 6 without carrying out works
Claim appears to be pretext for eviction
tenant_defenses: Works can be carried out with tenant in situ
No genuine intention to carry out works
Landlord has not owned property for 2 years
No planning permission or building approval
Landlord's previous Ground 6 claims did not result in works
Offer to vacate temporarily during works
notes: Ground 6 is MANDATORY but heavily scrutinized. Courts require strong evidence of genuine intention and necessity. Landlords often fail due to inadequate evidence or 2-year ownership rule. Works must actually be substantial - not just redecoration.
case_law: Wansbeck District Council v Marley [1988] - Works must be substantial, not just repairs
Ibie v Trubshaw [2000] - Must prove works cannot be done with tenant in occupation
Heath v Drown [1973] - 'Substantial' means more than minor or trivial
Daejan Properties v Mahoney [1995] - Landlord must have genuine intention at time of hearing
court_considerations: Are the proposed works genuinely substantial?
Can the works reasonably be carried out with tenant remaining?
Does landlord have genuine intention (not just to get vacant possession)?
Has landlord owned property for 2+ years?
Is there evidence of funding and professional planning?
What is the tenant's situation and potential hardship?
